author: medicyp
content:
Hi all,

could anybody help me to decypher this formula from Vitalik (showing the yield depending on staked amount)?:
https://twitter.com/vitalikbuterin/status/1326445197526331392?lang=en


exp(31556926 / 384 * 64 / 31622 / total_staked ** 0.5) - 1
i can understand it except for why there is an exponential of 0.5 above (like why 0.5 and not 0.25 for example). I am doing advanced mathematic research on Proof of Stake systems

Kindly let me know if it is not the best channel to ask this question

author: jgm
content: It's down t how you handle rewards with a variable number of validators.  At one end of the scale you can have constant rewards per validator, at the other you can have total constant rewards.  The square root provides a middle ground, where total rewards increase with the number of validators, but rewards per validator decline.  This allows rewards to not be too much per validator when the number of validators is small, but not so much in total when the number of validators is large.

author: medicyp
content:
ok very interesting, thanks a lot!
So basically the square root is a middle ground, I see.

If instead of a middle ground at "^0.5" (i.e. square root), we had "1", I guess that the reward would evolve more gradually? And if we had "^0.25", this would evolve more "exponentially"? 

Do you think it would make sense to tweak this variable in a PoS system (i am talking about even more broadly than ethereum) to change the incentive mechanism for the stakers? Or is 0.5 really the only number which would make sense?

author: medicyp
content: i plotted ethereum policy on Python following vitalik's tweet:

author: medicyp
content:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np
import math
import matplotlib.ticker as mtick

# source: https://twitter.com/vitalikbuterin/status/1326445197526331392?lang=en
power_variable = 0.5
seconds_per_year = 31556926
seconds_per_epoch = 384
base_reward_factor = 64
sqrt_of_gwei_per_eth = (10 ^ 9) ^  power_variable

# PART 1: Amount depending on yield
def calc_staked(reward_yield):
    return ((seconds_per_year / seconds_per_epoch * base_reward_factor / sqrt_of_gwei_per_eth / (math.log(reward_yield +1))) ** ( 1 / power_variable) )

# 100 linearly spaced numbers
x = np.linspace(0.05,0.20,100)

# the function
vectorized_calc_staked = np.vectorize(calc_staked)
y = vectorized_calc_staked(x)

# setting the axes at the centre
fig = plt.figure()
ax = fig.add_subplot(2, 1, 1)
plt.ticklabel_format(style = 'plain')
ax.xaxis.set_ticks_position('bottom')
ax.xaxis.set_major_formatter(mtick.PercentFormatter())
ax.yaxis.set_ticks_position('left')

# plot the function
x_in_percent = x * 100
y_in_million_of_token = y * 10000000
plt.plot(x_in_percent,y, 'r')

# plot the labels
plt.title("Ethereum yield policy (Demand)")
plt.xlabel("Yield (%)")
plt.ylabel("Staked Amount (in ETH)")

# show the plot
plt.show()

author: medicyp
content:
this is the code to clarify.

Basically I am wondering if it would make sense to change "power_variable" in this code to change the incentive mechanism (like giving more tokens to early stakers, etc...)

author: jgm
content:
The axes are more commonly the other way around, but that looks about right.

Could the square root be a different power?  Sure, and there's no magic as to why a square root is the perfect solution, but it provides the two things I listed and works.

author: medicyp
content:
yep i inversed both axis because i wanted to have a look at "protocol" side. Protocol "chooses" the yield they want to offer in order to get a specific amount of validators they target

yep commonly this is the other way around, this is stakers having a look at the chart and looking at how much yield they would get

author: medicyp
content:
ok ok.

So you think 0.5 is kind of a working solution but this could be potentially tweaked in PoS system???

I do think 0.5 is the simplest way to have a look at it.

author: medicyp
content: did you get this graph by running a specific code? Do you have the source (URL or code?)?

author: jgm
content:
You probably want to start with what you are attempting to do and then pick the maths that supports it.  If you have no initial stakers you may want to increase the yield at low numbers.  If you want a stable monetary model you may want fixed issuance, _etc._  The numbers themselves are arbitrary in that they can be altered, but were chosen to meet certain aims.

There are probably commentary on this in either Vitalik's or Ben's annotated Ethereum specs.

(Graph came from the same equation just with reversed axes.)

author: medicyp
content: yep agreed, thanks a lot for the interesting discussion
